0.user_question: What is the remainder when $129^{34}+96^{38}$ is divided by $11$?

ost_step.1: By Fermat's Little Theorem, since $11$ is prime, $129^{\phi(11)}=129^10\equiv 1\pmod{11}$, so $129^{34}=(129^{10})^3\cdot 99\equiv 1^3\cdot (-2)\equiv -2\pmod{11}$.
ost_step.2: Similarly, $96^{38}=(96^{10})^3\cdot 96^8\equiv 9^{-3}\cdot 96^8\pmod{11}$. To compute $9^k\pmod{11}$ repeatedly using modular exponentiation rules until you get your desired power k. Doing it once more yields $9^3=-5$, yielding our expression equal to $$-5\cdot 5^8.$$Now do similar work again starting from here as before till you reach the needed degree ($8$). That leaves us with $$-5\cdot 5^8\equiv -5\cdot 5\cdot 5^6\equiv -25\cdot (-1)^{3/2} =\color{#FF4F00}-25.\]So finally$$129^{34}+96^{38}\equiv -2+\color{#FF4F00}{\large{-25}}=-27\equiv -\color{red}{6}\pmod {11}$$and thus $$\bbox[yellow]{\text{the remainder requested is }-\color{blue}{6}}.$$
ost_step.3: Note also how working out remainders over primes helps greatly because multiplying any sequence remains results in another such sequence; e.g., taking $a\equiv b\pmod m,$ leads immediately to $ac\equiv bc\pmod m.$ Thus one may freely multiply together congruence relations without worrying about extra reduction steps afterwards.This allows much simplification even during intermediate calculation stages like above!
ost_step.4: There might appear some errors due mainly being done mentally but rest assured – those shouldn't affect overall accuracy too drastically unless carelessly made along way through process.. If found let me know & I shall update accordingly ;) . Hopefully everything checks fine now though :) Good luck w/ math problems going forward ;-) Thankyou!!
ost_step.5: The answer is: 6 or equivalently -6 depending upon convention. Let's consider both cases separately.

Notably important here is recognizing how powerful Fermat’s little theorem is; if p doesn’t divide m then phi($p$) | (m − 1) which helps greatly reduce large exponentiation problems since $$a^{\phi{(p)}} \equiv 1 \; (\text{mod }p)$$ Applying some smart algebraic manipulation yields:\[\begin{array}{|lrcll|} \hline & 129^{34} &\equiv&  8^{34} \\ &=& ((8^5)^{6})\\ &\equiv& ((8^5)(8^5)^{5}} \\ &=& ((8^5)(-5)^{5}}\;\because\; 8^{5} \equiv -1\,(\mod \,11))\\&=& ((8^{-5})(-5)^{5})\;\because\; 8^{10} \equiv 1\,\,(mod\,11)} \\ &\equiv& ((8^{-1}(-5)^{5}))\;&\color{gray}{\text{since}\,8^{10}\equiv1~(\text{by Fermat’s Little Theorem})}\\ &=&((3(-5)^{5}))\;&\color{gray}{\text{using shortcut calc instead of doing long multiplication manually}}\\ &=& ((3 * (-3)\times -5^2 )\\ &=& 325\equiv 1\;(\text{use calculator rather than tedious manual caluclation)}\end{array}$$and similarly,\[\begin{array}{|lrrcl|} \hline & 96^{38}& \equiv&{-5}^{38} \\ &=& ((-5^2)^{19}) \\ &\equiv&((-5)^{-1})^2(-5^{36})\\ &\equiv& ((5^{-1})^2(-5^{36}))\\ &\equiv& ((2(-5)^{36}))\\ &\equiv& ((2(-3)^2(1)^6))\;\color{gray}{\text{notice power reduces nicely thanks to smaller values being easy to work w

direct_answer.text:
To solve for the remainder when \(129^{34}+96^{38}\) is divided by \(11\), let's break it into manageable parts while considering the hint provided:

Step 1: Reduce each base modulo \(11\). From Hint 1 and Hint 2, we get:
$$129 \equiv 8 \pmod{11}$$
$$96 \equiv -5 \pmod{11}$$
Thus, we rewrite the original equation as follows:
$$129^{34} + 96^{38} \equiv 8^{34} + (-5)^{38} \pmod{11}$$
Since both bases raised to even exponents remain negative under modulus \(11\) but opposite signs compared to those bases cubed times five less one would give us similar results based on symmetrical parities within cyclic groups such as \(\mathbb{Z}_{11}^\times\). For instance, squaring twice brings you back to your starting position counterclockwise around said cycle—hence why raising them up another layer won't change sign relative positions among other elements present once further iterated iterations complete before

0.user_question: What is the remainder when $129^{34}+96^{38}$ is divided by $11$?

subanswer.text: Using modular arithmetic rules or trial division, we have $r_1=8$ because $129 \equiv 8(\mod 11)$. The answer is $r_1=8$.
Similarly, using modular arithmetic rules or trial division, we have $r_2=-5$ because $96 \equiv -5(\mod 11)$. The answer is $r_2=-5$.

4.subquestion: Now we can answer the question: What is the sum of the remainders after adding them together, and what does this mean regarding the final expression \(({129}^{34}+96^{38})\) under divisor Question 5.5

subanswer.text: Adding up the previous computed remainders provides us $$\boxed{1+(−1)=\boxed{0}}.$$ This indicates that ${129}^{34}+96^{38}$ is perfectly divisible by 11 without leaving a residue term remaining at the end. Thus indeed confirming once more why so much effort went into breaking down individual component computations within larger expressions — their collective addition may produce significant insights beyond mere summation!

0.user_question: What is the remainder when $129^{34}+96^{38}$ is divided by $11$?

subanswer.text: To calculate $129 \equiv r_1 (\mod 11)$, you need to determine the value of $r_1$ such that when divided into both sides of the congruence produces the same remainder upon division by 11. You do it as follows: Divide 129 by 11 and get quotient Q=11\*11=121, reminder R=129-RQ=129-121=8 so $129 \equiv 8(\mod 11)$. Thus ,the correct option according your choices would be 'E'. Hence, Option E ($r_1 \equiv 8$) satisfies our equation i.e., $129 \equiv 8(\mod 11)$.

direct_answer.text: We know that any exponentiation operation modulo some prime p does not affect multiplication due to Fermat’s Little Theorem which states that for every nonnegative integer a not divisible by prime p, the following holds true : $$a^{(p-1)}≡1~~~mod~~~p$$Applying similar logic here considering primes 11;let us break up exponents using above theorem.$$129^{\large {34}}=(129^{\underline {10}}\cdot129^{\underline {-6}}) \cdot\\[6pt]  96^{\large {38}}= (96^{\underline {10}}\cdot96^{\underline {-2}}) . \\[6pt] ~~~~~~\text{[Note: Here powers underlined represent multiples of }~~10.]$$Using Fermat's little theorem:$129^{\underline {10}}\equiv_{11}1$,and similarly,$96^{\underline {10}}\equiv_{11}1$,since $$\Large n={\rm ord}_{11}(ab)=\gcd({\rm ord}_pa, {\rm ord}_{b})$$Thus rewriting expressions obtained before,we finally obtain:(
